The third foundational lie builds on the other two, and contemplates what is to be done with those who are not related to us, who have not earned life. 

The third lie is that violence redeems. 

So here's me, writing in the faraway & distant land of 2017:

www.the-reframe.com/a-more-redee...
A bubble hides one's own motives and beliefs from oneself—which suggests that the way to pop a bubble is from within. So, in these cases I try to always remember to first say *I.*

The third foundational lie is about violence that makes you feel safe. No—not you. 

Me. 

Violence that makes *me* feel safe, when it does—because the idea of "Bubbles" is that a bubble is a mirror that doesn't let one see oneself.

The second foundational lie is that life must be earned; that humanity is marked by scarcity, not plenty; that some have earned life and that others have not, and that because those who have not earned life have not earned it, they don't deserve life or the things that bring life.
The first foundational lie is that we aren't related to one another; that human society is marked not by connection but by separation.

"Bubbles" suggests that we need to change our national spirit is because our current national spirit is founded on terrible lies, a spirit that wants and enacts genocide and slavery. 

And then it lays out the foundational lies.

This essay is a part of a series called "Bubbles," which I wrote in the first half of 2017. Some of you might have read it back then, and the rest of you haven't, and I love you very much either way.

The real question posed is, why do the power structures of our society choose the left hand, at scale, to this neighborhood, and to thousands of other neighborhoods like it?

In 1989, everyone wanted Spike Lee to answer the question: Do you think Mookie did the right thing? What people missed was, Spike Lee had already answered the question, in the movie, for anyone who wanted to pay attention.

In fact, while the police killing was mostly seen as violence, the act of policing Black neighborhoods didn't seem to be acknowledged as being violence at all. 

Like I said, sometimes when people talk about art, the art starts talking about them.

I think the reaction to Do the Right Thing revealed that the burning of a white-owned pizzeria represented violence that scared white audiences, while a persistent police presence in a Black neighborhood that might at any moment turn into the murder of one of that neighborhood's residents did not.

I see a film that is about the ways that policing in America represent the ongoing persistent historical violence that was already and overwhelmingly being condoned by the very audiences that were most concerned about how a film might be condoning violence.

So I'd argue this isn’t a movie about the moral ramifications of riots or of the destruction of Sal’s Pizzeria, but rather a movie concerned with the horrific effects of policing on Black neighborhoods.

Yet the movie rather pointedly ends with listing of many names of Black people who had been murdered by the police in recent years—a reminder that police brutality was very much a thing even back in 1989, just like it is now, when cell phone video makes it much harder to ignore.

WAS this a movie about the riots and the destruction of property? Mostly white pundits and audiences seemed to think so, expressing concerns that Do the Right Thing might incite Black people to riot. 

Few seemed to also worry that police brutality might cause riots.

Mostly white audiences decided that this was a movie about whether destruction of property is justified by an act of police brutality. The tragic burning of Sal’s Pizzeria was discussed at length. 

The tragic destruction of Radio Raheem’s body didn’t come up quite so much.

People really wanted Spike Lee to say Mookie was wrong. Spike Lee declined. 

The potential condoning of violence became a major issue that audiences had with the movie—and by violence, I mean the riot, and the destruction of Sal's Famous Pizzeria.

The riot begins when Mookie, the pizzeria's delivery man, and a friend of Radio Raheem's, hurls a trash can through the pizzeria's window. 

When the movie came out, this ending was controversial—VERY controversial.

In the movie's devastating finale there is an ugly and entirely avoidable confrontation that ends with a police murder of a young Black man named Radio Raheem; it's a murder that sparks a riot in which a local pizzeria is burned down.

You like these people, and even though there’s a fair amount of strife that bubbles up in the heat, you don’t want this day to end. 

But it ends. 

I’m going to spoil this 35-year-old movie now. Consider yourself duly warned.

It’s a gorgeous portrait of a community of often very messy and complicated people who despite their flaws and rough edges and bigotries, the film seems to very much enjoy being around—and because of this, we very much enjoy being around them too.

People can comment on art; this is known. Less discussed is the fact that art can comment on people.

I felt that way because, if that were true, creating a world of justice would require nothing of me, and any instance of injustice was just that—an instance, a blip that our self-perfecting system would correct automatically, and something that did not obligate me at all.

I can speak to the motive for my beliefs, back when I believed that our system was inherently just, that racism was a conquered thing of the past best examined in history’s rearview mirror, and that polarization was a more present threat than injustice. 

My motive was comfort.

Poochie’s anti-anger project expands the margins of permission for those who would defend and promote the systemic injustices that are the cause of that anger. 

And yeah, I can't speak to his motives. But I once believed similar things. 

I know what MY motives were.

Poochie’s case is that anger in response to injustice’s violence is a far more present threat and a far greater danger to society than the violence of injustice itself, because to Poochie, polarized anger is not an outcome of injustice and violence, but rather is its cause.

This a move that serves to cover the entire observably supremacist anti-woke project with a sort of exonerating blanket that is not only understandable, but pro-Black. 

Is this purposeful? Who can say? 

Also who cares.

He does this not by advocating for anti-wokeness himself, but by pointing to a version of "anti-woke" written by a Black writer, and using him as a stand-in for an anti-woke movement that is observably supremacist, even if he may not even be making the same rhetorical points.

This suggests Poochie actually doesn’t understand the position he says he agrees with, and never really tries, preferring instead to understand the view that he claims he opposes—understand it so much in fact, that he spends his time defending and promoting it.

It never seems to occur to Poochie that the reason the people he claims he agrees with are so angry is not because they *don’t* understand the argument of the anti-woke supremacist spirit, but because they *do* understand it.

My Poochie does this is by utilizing a very common strategy, that is, seeking such justifiably angry people out and spamming them with the message that actually anti-woke people have an *understandable* perspective if you’ll just stop to understand it.

I'm interrogating and critiquing all the Poochies out there (my Poochie is one among many), and the fact that all these Poochies have decided the thing to combat is not systemic injustice but the anger people feel toward those who promote and defend systemic injustice.

I mention McWhorter, not to interrogate or critique his premises or his intentions, other than to note the fact that he appears to hold some sort of opposition to some version of something that he calls “woke.”

However, I *am* interrogating and critiquing Poochie.

Maybe someday I should read McWhorter's book, and maybe I’ll learn something new. The summary doesn’t leave me too hopeful on that score; it sounds like stuff I’ve already heard before from people who would rather not be bothered about injustice. But I've been wrong before.

And I really have no standing to question the path by which a Black man in the United States came to his understanding of racism in the United States, or what it is to be Black in the United States, nor do I have any desire to do so. 

So I won't be doing that.

Now, I want to be clear that I haven’t read John McWhorter’s stuff, so I can’t really comment on it, and I don’t have a strong enough sense of his premise to know if what he means when he says “woke” aligns with what your average white supremacist means when they say it.

McWhorter is an associate professor of linguistics at Colombia University, which is a place anti-woke people insist nobody is allowed to express anti-woke thoughts without having their career destroyed, and he seems to be enjoying a nice career there, and good for him I say.

McWhorter does indeed seem to be some form of something called “anti-woke.” He wrote a book called Woke Racism, written (as I take it from summaries) in opposition to the entire project of antiracism, and which positions antiracism as an effort that actually *increases* racism.
And pretty much every time Poochie says this, he also says that in order to understand the anti-woke position, you might be interested in the work of John McWhorter.

In the mentions of various people’s social media, Poochie wants you to know, dozens and hundreds of identically-phrased times, that there are actually perfectly *understandable* reasons that somebody might be anti-woke.

Poochie will also make sure you know that he isn’t anti-woke; he’s just anti-anger; against people being angry at the rhetorical and political goals of people who call themselves anti-woke, because anger increases polarization, and polarization, again, is the true danger.

People who think others need their permission to be allowed to exist are supremacists, btw, because among other things they think that their own psychological comfort within their made-up worldview is more important other people’s actual lives. 

Anyway, let's get back to Poochie.

And they are making THAT case to establish themselves as the people who should get to bestow permission upon what jobs should be permitted, and in what other ways that Black people and other systemically marginalized people should be allowed to exist in society.

They're blaming Black pilots in order to make the larger case that Black people should not be hired for any sort of important (e.g. well-paying) jobs without the express permission of them, the white supremacists who see Black faces in important positions as a clear danger.

Once you can say that you’re anti-woke instead of saying you’re a supremacist, then you can say all sorts of supremacist things. 

These days white supremacists are blaming the very existence of Black pilots for plane crashes in general. 

Good times!

"Anti-woke," as you might guess, is simply the state of being against things that are “woke” by supremacist definitions; an organized and energetic supremacist opposition to awareness in general and the demand for equality and diversity and inclusion and equity in particular.

They used "woke" to mean "deserves even more accelerated and entrenched systemic abuse and state-sanctioned violence.” 

And now in many states there are laws that make it dangerous for teachers to teach about Black history, and for trans people to live at all, and on and on.

They claimed “woke” for themselves and used it to mean a whole raft of things that boil down to “the existence of people we supremacists do not consider to be valid is not only annoying but threatening, not only threatening but existentially dangerous."

Recently, white supremacists who wanted to defend the systemic nature of injustice, and who knew that awareness represents the beginning of the end for these sorts of things, did what such people usually do when they see something Black people own that they want: they stole it.

Anyway, one of Poochie's topics is anti-wokeness, about which I’ve written a bit. For a brief refresher, “woke” is a term Black people coined many yrs ago to describe their growing awareness of the systemic nature of injustice in general & white supremacist racism in particular.

Less than 24 hours later, King was dead; as dead as the dominant economic and military superpower of his age had hoped he would become.

I like that; the idea of ending a speech about necessary work with a picture of arriving at the top of a mountain. Climbing a mountain takes intentional work, and provides a view that would be unavailable to anyone who didn’t do that work. 

Yes, I like that picture very much.

He talked about going to the mountaintop, which was a picture from scripture of Moses, the leader of a nation of enslaved people who had escaped enslavement, watching from the mountain at the end of his life as the people he had led entered their land.

In the Mountaintop speech, King spoke of the work of repair that was needed and the unsustainability of any land that refused to do it, and he spoke of the inevitable strife that would attend that unsustainability.

A lot of Republicans and members of other white supremacist groups would have it that King only gave that one misquoted line from that one speech, but he gave many others. The last of them is known as the Mountaintop speech, and it was delivered in Memphis in solidarity with striking workers there.

The main themes of King's Dream speech were of all the ways the dream had not been made true, the unsustainability of that injustice, the inevitability of strife and unrest until justice's advent, and the need to do the work of repair—which are less popular themes with white supremacists.

White supremacists misquote King in part because they don't actually care about what he stood for, and in part because they'd like to try to steal from him the one thing they'll can't take and will never have: his moral authority.

Annual reminder that King didn't say *people* should be judged by their character rather than their skin. He said he dreamed of a future day when *his children* would live in such a state, while observing they did not; that U.S. had never delivered on its founding promises.

They insist on this debate, and they insist upon it from every possible position, any of which they can easily take, precisely because people with no beliefs beyond their own supremacy are comfortable acting in bad faith in order to achieve their eliminationist ends.

People of bad faith, such as fascists and other supremacists, know this. It’s why they are so insistent on endless debate over their unacceptable positions. And other people of bad faith who enable them know this, too, which is why they are so eager to grant them that debate.

As a context, debate signals to everyone watching “the debaters are reasonable and knowledgeable people with good intentions, and the propositions being debated are all reasonable outcomes that reasonable people consider reasonable, and which you may feel consider also, and be found reasonable.”

In the same way, only somebody who is committed to gardening will use a trowel to garden. A murderer will find other uses. See the difference? 

The shared reality, and what that reality shares—that is the thing.

If two people occupy a shared reality based on grotesque anti-human lies, and are both facing a problem that they agree is a problem, and problems are defined as the existence of other types of human beings, debate will only facilitate a more efficient and more complete atrocity.

If two people occupy a shared reality, based on observable and provable facts, and are both facing a problem that they agree is a problem, and problems are defined as obstacles to the thriving of all humans, then debate can be an excellent tool for facilitating human thriving.

Here’s what I think debate is: a sharpening tool that creates a normalizing context. It will sharpen any argument, and it will sharpen the debating tactics of those who debate, no matter whether they wish to inspire us to cure cancer, or to murder millions of our fellow humans.

I think debate *can* help people arrive at the best ideas and solutions, but I don’t think debate *creates* a healthy society. I think it is only if you already have a healthy society with a good definition of what is good that those people will ever use debate to find good ideas

A popular notion regarding debate is that it is the tool needed to create the healthiest society and the most open discourse, which it accomplishes by hashing out competing ideas and arriving, invariably, at the best one. 

I have a different view.

So I’d say it’s pretty important to be able to recognize bad faith in our debates. That’s what I’d like to do today. Most of the time I’m pretty abstract. Today I’d like to get tactical and specific. 

But first: what exactly is a debate for?

I conclude that this means we ought never to give people with eliminationist intent the benefit of doubt of good intent. As long as we keep doing this, eliminating other humans will be something we debate, and that is a topic that can never be engaged in good faith.

And that’s why bad faith posturing—denial, accusation, reversal of victim and offender—is so effective for any type of narcissistic abuser, but most definitely effective for fascists and other types of supremacists with eliminationist intentions toward their fellow human beings.

You will not be shunned or chased away by most decent people, because you have spent the preceding weeks pretending to be something you are not, and everyone will have spent those weeks finding common ground, not with what you are, but with what you have pretended to be.

And then a few weeks later you could take to the airwaves to defend your leader's Hitler quotes, by positioning the existence of migrants as a poison in the blood. 

This would not be bad faith b/c for once it aligns with your actual supremacists beliefs and eliminationist intent.

And you could portray them as antisemitic not to combat antisemitism, but simply to further your party’s decades-long efforts to demolish and discredit universities specifically and education generally. 

That would be bad faith, too. 

To give another example.

Then you could summon university presidents to Congress in order to portray them as antisemitic for adopting the exact sorts of far-right coddling practices you have spent decades insisting they adopt in the name of free speech, even though you don’t believe in free speech.

This would allow you to pretend to be against antisemitism in theory while belonging to a political organization that is doing everything it can to promote antisemitic hatred and violence in actual life. 

That would be bad faith. 

To give one example.

Now if all that were true, you might for example work to promote your eliminationist ends by attempting to redefine “antisemitism” to mean “opposition to eliminationism,” and then you might try to define people who protest eliminationist practices as antisemitic.

This means that you and your party have been participants in a decades-long deliberate coordinated effort to demolish and discredit the university system specifically and the educational system generally and the very idea of knowable truth as a concept.
Now say that, in order to enact eliminationist brutality you find it useful to demolish and discredit things like awareness and knowledge and learning and the concept of knowable truth.

Say also you belong to a political party whose leader is an open fascist who approvingly quotes Hitler in order to promote a conspiracy theory called ‘replacement’ that forms the undergirding bedrock of antisemitism, to better enact eliminationist brutality against refugees.

Promoting ideas and actions in the name of some fine thing that you don’t believe in and might actually oppose is what is meant when someone says "bad faith."

I’ve talked about DARVO - an acronym that stands for deny, accuse, reverse victim and accuser, and names tactics of abusers.

In recent weeks I’ve been talking about the bully tactics of narcissist abusers, and how American fascists and other supremacists use them to push out the boundaries of acceptable violence against those they intend to target. 

These bully tactics are Chris Rufo’s tactics.

I remember supremacist beginning assumptions and the eliminationist ends, and I realize that to participate in the discussion about these things within that framework will in no way solve any problems at all; it will only participate in a cynical opportunistic attempt at eliminationist supremacism.

This isn’t because none of those things are worth considering. I daresay most are worth considering, and some are maybe even vitally important to consider. Maybe all are. 

It’s just that I am looking at the full picture. 

I see the frame and I see who did the framing.

You’ll notice I haven’t spent time talking about the merits of the accusation against Claudine Gay, or whether or not our elite academic institutions have structural problems needing redress, or any other aspect of the story that has been the obsessive focus of much of our media in recent weeks.

But he does care about defending and reinforcing supremacy, and he sees these fine ethics and principles as useful tools to attack ethical principles that work to name and dismantle supremacy. 

And they *are* useful tools for him, mostly because so many of us let him use them.

I stress again that he doesn’t care about these principles or values at all. In fact, he is working to demolish them, which you can easily tell by looking at the ends he pursues, and you can even more easily tell by listening to him say so in so many words before he does it.

Chris Rufo—who has no ethics or principles beyond supremacy—does all this this while appealing to various principles that people who do have principles beyond supremacy care about—things like equality and fairness, or, for as long as it is convenient to him, academic integrity.

He does this in part to eliminate an individual whose authority and influence defies his personal individual supremacy, and in part he does it in order to discredit the work and the programs and the institutions that defy supremacy on the larger scale.
Chris Rufo also targets institutions that elevate such people to positions of authority and influence, and he does this to demolish them and their reputations and their authority and their influence.

Because this is what he believes, Chris Rufo targets r people who are not part of the existing preferred classes but who have still committed the aggressive crime against Chris Rufo of holding positions of authority and influence without his permission.

If somebody is not one of these things, but still agrees to uphold supremacy, that candidate might be permitted by Chris Rufo to be considered the best candidate, but in any case Chris Rufo wants to make it clear that he is the person who gets to bestow permission.
And if the person is somebody whose work focuses on naming and deconstructing supremacist intentions and institutions, then by *best candidate* he definitely means somebody else, anybody else.
Yes, and if the person who holds the position is a women, then by best candidate Chris Rufo means a man—which is already the preferred class, when it comes to positions of authority and influence.

But for Chris Rufo, “white” is automatically baked into the definition of “best candidate,” and the absence of “white” is a priori evidence that the “best candidate” has not been selected—so diversity, equity, and inclusivity are to him a corrupt outrage and a violent crime.

The ways our systems select for “white” are so entrenched, in fact, that if an institution is serious about finding the actual best candidate, it needs to deliberately create programs in place to consciously and intentionally swim against the existing societal current.
If the person who holds the position is Black, then by “best candidate,” Chris Rufo means somebody white—which is already the preferred class, when it comes to positions of authority and influence.

The supremacist *best candidate* is a sort of mythical beast, so the attempt to categorize it will be something similar to cryptozoology. 

Nevertheless, I will make my best effort.

The *best candidate* is a very big deal with supremacists, I’ve noticed. It’s an appeal to fairness and equality and merit from people who don’t care about fairness and equality or merit, who are in fact diametrically opposed to those principles and are working to demolish them.

The assumption is that any position so held represents an obvious theft that deserves redress, and a presumed outrage that deserves retribution, on behalf of the *best candidate,* who should hold the position instead, and has been improperly kept from their rightful place.

Chris Rufo begins with a supremacist assumption. 

The assumption is that any person holding a position of authority or influence, who does not in some way represent supremacy’s existing preferred classes to the satisfaction of those classes, holds that position illegitimately.

This problem is bigger than Chris Rufo, who isn’t the first right-wing media agitator opportunistically destroying societal institutions; he’s just one of the more successful and brazen current examples. But we can look at how he operates to see how supremacy operates.

He’s very open about his supremacist assumptions—which would be his beginnings. 

He’s very open about his eliminationist intentions—which would be his ends. 

You might even say he’s brazen, as if he knows ignoring the bad assumptions and intentions is how his whole thing works.

Chris Rufo is a far-right supremacist agitator who uses bad faith techniques to opportunistically exploit weaknesses inherent in our institutions. 

The way I know that this is what Chris Rufo is and that this is what he does is quite simple. I know it because he says so—out loud.

If you want the whole picture, you’d better make sure you can see the frame, and if you want the entire story, you need the beginning and the end. 

I’m afraid explaining what I mean involves making some of you aware of Chris Rufo.

The Nobles left their home state because they were being eliminated by their state government. The Nobles were, and are, in serious danger.

The Huckinses left their state because of insufficient elimination of unwanted people. The Huckinses are the danger that others are in.

Maybe we should look past stated intent and start looking at what actually happened. Here's how I would describe it:

The Nobles needed safety. 

The Huckinses wanted to feel safe.

Perhaps the distinction needs a bit more explanation.

But I was talking about the Huckinses, who left their home state seeking safety—the exact same motivation as the Nobles, is what I’m meant to understand.

But look here, we shouldn’t be uncharitable. The intent was safety, which is a good thing. And we all want safety. Who would be against safety?

Anyway, everywhere around this country, cities whose governments have agreed to the general supremacist premises engage in a policy of elimination of unhoused people, in the name of safety, while state governments pursue policies that ensure people will fall into poverty and lose access to housing.

So that might be an answer to those who fret about the cost of caring for people in need: the cost of not caring for people in need appears to be a growing population of desperate people, and increasingly costly municipal brute squads.

And I suppose an unhoused person does represent a bit of danger. People who are neglected to the point of desperation often become desperate is my observation, and desperation does not make a person make the safest decisions.

There are good upstanding citizens in every city who will go out and rob and harass and harm and murder unhoused people for free, yet even so, most of our cities spend half of their budgets or more on municipal brute squads who are given military equipment to do the same job.

We should say more about unhoused people. 

Unhoused people are without question the most at-risk population in our country, in greatest danger of harassment and abuse, harm and murder, and of being refused access to basic needs like food and water and shelter and medical care.

They are in danger.

The issue for the Huckinses is that they felt that their hometown of Portland had not yet eliminated unhoused people quite enough for their taste, so they moved to the exurbs of Saint Louis, Missouri, where unhoused people—who are the most at-risk people in society—have been sufficiently eliminated.

The Nobles moved because one of their children is trans, and the government of their home state of Iowa has decided that it would be better if trans people didn’t exist quite so much in Iowa, and have—like almost every other Republican-controlled state—passed a law to make that happen.

The Nobles moved from Iowa to neighboring Minnesota because they wanted to be safe, and they weren’t. If you ask the Huckinses, they moved from Oregon to Missouri for the same reason. So it’s the same intention, on both sides, apparently.

Let's look at what is actually happening.

It’s about a trend of families who move from their home state to another state, because of political differences. That’s the way the story is framed. Two families, who both moved for basically the same reason. The story tells us that this demonstrates our increased political polarization.

The Huckinses and the Nobles were two families covered in a profile piece by the New York Times. You can read it if you want, right here.

www.nytimes.com/2023/10/07/u...

So I conclude that intention is a matter of what is actually done, not what is claimed.

I’d suggest this means that it is very important to pay attention to what is actually done.

Let’s return to the Nobles and the Huckinses.

Republicans created an incentive system whereby university presidents would be a group uniquely reluctant to unequivocally oppose hate speech, would be people most likely to draft lawyerly equivocating answers and policies to the exact question “would you accept genocidal talk on your campus?”

Then, after decades of this, Republicans this week called university presidents onto the carpet and made enormous amounts of political hay over the fact that university weren’t opposing a hypothetical instance of hate speech sufficiently or vociferously enough.

I think I'd better say that again.

Republicans spent a solid decade insisting that university presidents make their campuses bastions of "free speech" specifically by allowing marginalizing and othering hate speech most specifically, and never suppressing it in any way, specifically to avoid chilling free speech by harming careers.

That’s right.

Republicans.

If you’ve been reading all along, this may all seem obvious and repetitive, but I believe it’s good to define your terms at the outset. And, in an age of empowered liars, I’ve found it can be instructive, even powerful, to repeat true things. Thanks for your patience.

You would not be an oppressor, because your view is not a lie, and power accommodating your view would not hurt the person you oppose or dismiss them or their identity; it would merely prevent them from doing the same to you.

I oppose you, but it is not my opposition to you that makes me oppressive, but rather my empowered, accommodated supremacy. 

If power agreed with you, for example, you would not be an oppressor, even though you oppose me. You would not be an oppressor, because your view is not a lie.

My view is accommodated over yours, even though my view is a lie, even though the accommodation hurts you and dismisses you and your identity. But what I believe is still a lie.

And I am still a supremacist asshole.

Say the legal and political apparatuses of our society also impose a reality under which I am the one who gets to decides the limits of your ability and your right to be. 

Now I am not just a supremacist, but an oppressor. 

I am an oppressor, because power agrees with my lie and enforces it.

Now, say I have more power behind me than just my own will. Let’s say the world is arranged in ways that force you to live in my lie instead of your truth. This doesn't make me right. It means the world has arranged itself around unsustainable lies to accommodate my supremacy.

Now, it also just so happens that you have beliefs of your own in this scenario. You believe I am a supremacist asshole. It so happens you are correct. 

"Supremacist" because I believe I have supremacy over you, and "asshole" because that is an asshole thing to believe.

"Unsustainable" because a society that believes that some people do not matter inevitably becomes a society optimized to destroy people, and a society optimized to destroy people will do that as long as there are people. 

So, if you’re a person, you might do well to oppose me.
Now it just so happens that I am wrong about all that. I actually believe a bunch of unsustainable lies about you and me and how society is supposed to work.

I’m establishing that my understanding of who you are is more important than your understanding of who you are. 

I’m establishing my license to permit you to exist. 

I'm establishing my supremacy over you as an excusive and natural right.

I am attempting to impose a reality founded on that belief, under which I am the one who gets to define you, and your right to exist is not a foregone conclusion but something that will be established and mediated by what I and other people who matter are comfortable allowing.

I am demonstrating an extremely popular core belief—I'd call it the dominant default core belief of American thought, particularly conservative thought—that there are people who matter, and I am one of those, and there are people who do not matter, and that you are one of those.

Perhaps you’ve seen this scenario play out in thousands of different ways, and wondered: What is that? I’ll tell you what it is. 

It’s supremacy. It’s a belief that I am supreme.

Let’s say this plays out in a number of other beliefs I have about your identity. Again and again, you establish yourself on your own terms; again and again I refuse your self, in a way that makes it clear my ability to accept or refuse you is a core part of how I see myself.

Say your name is Joe. You believe your name is Joe because that’s your name. I insist your name is Jean because I believe I have the right to name you, and that you do not have the right to name yourself, because of who I understand myself to be, and you to be.

armoxon.substack.com/p/how-to-tal...

And story reveals the difference. It’s one of the great uses of story, in fact. 

What using story demonstrates to people aligned with abusive power is that they can’t tell their own stories—not really. They can only borrow those of others and wear them around.

What using story does is expose why people of bad faith can’t tell their own stories as stories. The reason is, the person is operating in ostensibly good intent but bad faith. What we put our faith in determines our actions, and action is how you determine true intent.

So they have to tell a story where pure intent justifies any action. You can do this as long as you keep the bullshit spinning, but what I’ve noticed is that if you actually put a character who does those things onto the page or screen, they come off as a real asshole.

What I’ve noticed about abusive people is they always make themselves both the victim and the hero of their own stories: heroes of good intention, victimized by people who actually expect them to enact their stated good intentions as good policy and notice when they don't.

My point: What's happening is a critical mass of people are done putting up with abusive bullshit anymore—taking it or excusing it—and I think this seems very divisive and dangerous to people who rely on abusive bullshit for either fortune or identity. 

To demonstrate this, I look to story.

Ask them for their favorite story where the heroes made sure that only the deserving hungry got food, where only the deserving sick got care, and then only if it could be afforded without raising taxes. 

Tell them they can use their Bibles, if they want.

Or their favorite story about boss or the landlord who kept so much of their profit for themselves that they forced their employees to take second jobs. 

Or their favorite story about an insurance company who maximized profits for its shareholders.

Or their favorite story about a rich man who got a tax break and defunded schools and programs for those in need. 

Or their favorite story about a rich woman who taught poor parents a lesson by making sure hungry children didn’t get free lunch.

Ask them their favorite story about a society that valued property more than people, and profit more than life, and how much money they made, and how they won out over the guilt trips other people laid on them.

Or their favorite story about teachers who took a bully’s side, in order to make “normal” kids feel comfortable in the presence of a "different" kid.

Or their favorite story about a politically empowered minority who forced other people to live according to the strictures of their religion.

Ask them for their favorite story where the heroes targeted a marginalized group for exclusion and harm. 

Or their favorite story about library closings and book bans. Their favorite story about defunding school systems.

Or their favorite story about a billionaire who bribed a judge, or a bribed judge who overturned civil rights legislation, or who sued a journalist for exposing his corruption, or who defunded a public works project to protect his business interests.

Or their favorite story about a heroic strongman, who overthrew elections, called journalists the enemy, who referred to his ideological opponents vermin and vowed to expunge them by the millions from the country.
Ask them for their favorite story about how a dominant cultural and military superpower harnessed power and law and might to successfully prevent the group it was oppressing from being liberated.
Or their favorite story about a cop who killed a kid, or a well-fed vigilante who kept everyone safe by choking a homeless man.

Or their favorite story where a heavily militarized police force kept the impoverished neighborhoods they occupied perfectly subdued, on behalf of neighborhoods full of wealthier citizens who received a greater share of resources.

And then maybe ask them for their favorite story about the country that was brave enough to do whatever it took to feel safe, even going so far as to not only enact torture but praise it as an obvious good.
Ask them for their favorite story about the people who wisely separated the children of refugees from their parents, to better dissuade any other refugees from coming.
Ask them for their favorite story about the brave rich country that saved their society by building a wall around itself, to keep all the dirty poor invading hordes out.

Not the things they claim to intend with the politics, but the things those politics actually do. 

Ask them to tell the story where heroes build the world they insist upon, in other words. 

Ask them for their favorite story about a country that bravely booby-trapped its border.

So, ask. Ask about favorite stories. Movies, books, parables, whatever. Hear them out. 

Finally, thank them for all the story recommendations. 

And ask them about their favorite stories where people do the sorts of pragmatic, grown up things their politics actually enact.

Next, ask them about their favorite stories. When you tell a story, you can start with intention, but eventually you’re going to get into action or there’s no story. 

So, stories are about what actually happens when intent meets reality and activity, which will be useful later.

Here’s what I recommend. 

First, find that common ground. Acknowledge that we all agree that we care about good things, and for everyone, but we also seem to agree that at least some of us, despite our intentions, apparently believe horrible destructive things.

What I’m saying is, this probably won’t change any minds, but if you don’t care about keeping the peace, it might be fun. If your goal is keeping the peace, bite your tongue and grip the table. Time will pass; it always does.

Dry cracker of a caveat finished. Let's get to the meat and potatoes.

But then, I think a mind only changes if it opens itself to the possibility of changing itself, and if a mind that has opened in such a way, argument in opposition is going to help it along far more than a polite silence.

As a caveat: I don’t think this will work in the slightest, if your goal is keeping the peace or changing anybody’s mind—but then I think everyone is responsible for changing their own minds, and I don’t see argument changing minds.

And this suggests to me a method you can use to talk to people who are in your life, who care just as much as you do (and maybe even more) about things you care about, but who you can’t help but notice happen to be supporting people and policies that actively destroy all those things.

And who could fail to be charmed by somebody who can’t help themselves from suggesting—while seeking common ground—that not only are they *as* good in their intentions as you, but that their intentions are actually probably *better?*

So that’s cool. It’s nice to know that everyone cares so much about good things, and apparently wants good things for everyone. It’s great to understand how much good intention is wafting around the dining room along with the turkey smells.

The point Heritage is making is everyone intends good for everyone, *especially* conservatives. 

Intentions are the best, aren’t they? What’s fun about them is the way you can separate them from what actually happens, like turkey skin sloughing off of a perfect slab of white meat.

And then it goes on to say that progressive politics fail to create those things, so, sadly, they cannot support progressive politics, alack, alas. 

We could argue any number of those points, I suppose. But no, let us seek that sweet sweet common ground.

The Heritage methodology involves explaining that conservatives “care just as much as [liberals] do (maybe more) about clean air and water, helping the poor, ensuring no one goes without needed health care, and creating jobs so everyone has a chance to live the American Dream.”

The Heritage Foundation—a think tank that has architected the rough beast now known as modern conservatism—put out a version on the theme some years ago, one that recommends that you seek common ground with your familial libs.

I won't link to it, because I don't link to them. Find it if you want.

Here’s what I’ve got:

First, learn to recognize the difference between: 

Anger, toward a systemic abuse that refuses to honor the intrinsic immeasurable value carried by every human being, and 

Rage, the popular hateful instinct that defeats even itself by seeking to destroy that humanity.

What do we do about it? It’s hard to know. Some days it seems overwhelming. The desire for rage is so pervasive, it can be smothering. The rhetorical devices employed in service of rage are insidious and refractory and confusing, a funhouse mirror maze of hypocrisies and misdirection and lies.

Rage accelerates abuse.

Rage makes a manufactured scarcity even more scarce.

Most insidious of all, rage offers those who are abused an opportunity to participate in the abuse.

Rage is cowardly. 

Rage will never threaten abusive and corrupt supremacy, because rage agrees with abuse’s assumptions, and helps an abusive system select its next victims.

Rage’s response to harm is to demand more harm. The only idea it can muster to being punished is to manage punishment differently and more brutally. Its response to a manufactured lack is to demand more lack.

Rage is punitive. 

It has no answer to abuse but more abuse. It has no answer to violence but violence. It looks at a system that exists to consume people, notes that the system is consuming them, and then demands an even more predatory system, one that consumes somebody else first and worst.

Rage is unproductive and unimaginative. It can’t see outside of the rubric of lack into a rubric of plenty. It can’t imagine that there could ever possibly be enough to go around, and so it demands that life must be earned, and then demands to define who has and who has not earned it.

I call it rage.

Rage is what happens when anger surrenders to hate.

Rage is misdirected. With a bully’s instinct, rage focuses upon the least powerful people, those most left behind and marginalized, and cast them as the aggressors of whatever grievance they see.

It's a question—"how will you PAY?"— that will tell you, if you are observant, that deep down, perhaps without telling themselves, they have decided that it is sick people who should have to pay for being sick, have on some level decided that sick people deserve a system designed to wipe them out.

And if you suggest that maybe our healthcare system should *not* be designed to wipe people out, they ask you how you intend to *pay* for a system that is designed to heal people instead, which is how you know that deep down they think people have a measurable value, and sick people's value is low.

They think this, even though we can all see that it costs us more than any other developed country, and returns worse outcomes, and wipes people out financially every single day.

And remember again, the value of each person is indestructible and immeasurable.

We know it, know because extracting money from sick people what the system pursues as a first priority, and it does it to people in astonishing numbers each year.

It’s VERY profitable. Some people think this means it is the very best. I’m not kidding! They will tell you so without blushing!

It’s odd: even though “healing people” is the goal toward which most health care professionals are dedicated, “wiping out sick people and their loved ones financially, mentally, and spiritually” is what our health care system is designed to do.

We all know this, too.

I already knew this. We all know this. This incident just sort of brought the reality of it home to me; the great beast swam near my house, and its shadow fell on me, but then it swam on. Unless I am very lucky indeed, it will return, because it comes for most of us someday.

The size of the bill (even after insurance_, and the lack of transparency and abundance of bureaucracy it promised, also made it clear to me that if anything ever goes actually bad, then our healthcare system will wipe even lucky old me out financially, and probably mentally and spiritually, too.

Anyway, the other day I got the estimate of the bill from the insurance company. Both my wife and I are very blessed with adequate physical and mental health and so we can still work, and thus we can afford to pay this bill.

This isn't true for everyone, I know.

This is how I know that I was dealing with immeasurable worth that was both intrinsic and indestructible. The idea that my loved one might not be functioning as well as before did not remotely touch my feeling of their worth.

(To be clear, it didn’t go the wrong way and everyone is fine.)

A little while ago, somebody I love very much got sick and for a couple days it seemed as if despite medical care they might get worse in a very bad way, which was just about the most dreadful feeling imaginable, and an outcome that I would have paid every last penny I had to prevent.

All people have an intrinsic and indestructible worth that cannot be measured. 

That’s not true of everything. If a car stops functioning properly, it’s no longer as valuable as it was when it was functioning properly. 

Not so with people.

Treating opposition to hatred as a scarce commodity to save only for greatest need seems to show a strategy designed—not to ready us to oppose the “real” hate when at last the worst possible thing imaginable arrives, but to actively assist the worst possible thing to arrive unopposed.

Is a picture of Hitler on the scoreboard of a state university stadium an oversight? Who can say? Nobody, which seems to be the point. We might wonder: why ask that question for college football pregame trivia? Was it somebody’s idea of a joke? Was it an intentional signal of permission?

I wonder: If you own a Hitler uniform as a gag, where do you keep it when it isn’t Halloween? Is it in your closet all year? Maybe you put it in storage. 

Is it still as funny when it’s hanging in there?

The reality is, opposition to bullying is not a rare substance that can be depleted. It's a muscle to be exercised. The more we exercise it, the stronger it gets.

I think bullies know that, too.

The way you push the bully back is by revoking permission, not once it’s gone too far, but every time permission is tested, then revoking permission for bullying things that had previously been permitted. By drawing clear lines that harm is not acceptable, and then—crucially—*by not accepting it.*

What are Hanania and all the rest of them and their little games, after all, if not a bullying’s institution’s probing whiskers?—the toe over the line, the test at the margins, the way to determine that the harm that was unacceptable yesterday might be acceptable today?

All of this completely ignores—we might be tempted to say deliberately ignores—how bullies operate. The bully operates on a sliding scale of permission, and always start with the joke to see how the joke goes, and then tries maybe a little something else, and then a bit more, and a bit more.

We can’t ever oppose the hatred before us. We must always construct some hypothetical future worse hatred, and use the threat that it might someday appear before us, as a reason to refuse to oppose the real hatred that’s actually before us.

And another reason we mustn't oppose the oopsie-doodle hatred, the youthful indiscretion hatred, is that it doesn't leave any off-ramps from hatred for the bigot to take back to the rest of his, here in our allegedly anti-hatred mainstream that never seems to get around to actually opposing hatred.

And the reason we mustn't oppose the oopsie doodle hatred is because then we won’t be able to oppose real hatred when it arrives—as if opposition to hate is a precious substance, one that we might expend if we were to utilize it too immoderately.

There's this idea is that there is real earnest hatred, and then there’s just oopsie doodle fuckin’ around hatred, and we mustn’t waste our opposition to real hatred by spending it on those things that are only accidental, or only pretend and play and feints toward hatred.

What Hanania is saying these days only points toward the Nazism rather than trafficking in it directly; not saying the *most* terrible things, but only saying a lot of other things that are nearly as terrible, and are perfectly aligned with all of the most terrible things he said back then.

Actually—I tricked you just now.

Those aren’t the things he said that got him in trouble.

Everything I listed above are the things he’s saying *now*—the things he says that are on the *respectable* side of the border, which I’d argue tells us how far out the margins of permission have been pushed.

He wrote “We need more policing, incarceration, and surveillance of black people. Blacks won’t appreciate it, whites don’t have the stomach for it.”

And there’s more—a lot more.

Pretty bad, huh?

He suggested that Black people are inherently more given to violence, repeatedly equating blackness to criminality, writing that neighborhoods inhabited by majority Black populations are “uninhabitable.”

He wrote against the Civil Rights Act as a sort of original sin of the last century.

This was accomplished by framing cancellation of a rising racist media star as a far more dangerous thing than the rising media star of an open racist.

It might be worth looking at some things Hanania said that got him into such a pickle.

The exposure of Hanania’s unacceptable racism engendered the same cultural/media reaction these things always do, which was a quick and instinctual effort to rehabilitate him before he had even hinted he might do anything rehabilitative.

So Hanania's rising star was in danger of “cancellation,” which I am told is the most dangerous thing that can possibly happen in a free society, provided it is something vaguely reputational happening to a racist bully rather than something fatally violent happening to a Black teenager.

Well you’ll never guess what, but this professional racist also used to write for *overtly* white supremacist publications, issuing opinions that land well on what is currently the unsafe side of racism, which created scandal in a way that his normal ongoing racism hadn't.

What I mean by "professional mainstream racist" that he is paid to say some rather mainstream things with some very racist things mixed in, in a way that just skirts the safe edge of what mainstream captains of influence are willing to promote in as a fair-minded airing of “both sides.”

So now let’s talk about the United States’ fleet of well-paid professional hate launderers.

For example: Richard Hanania, who has managed to carve out a lucrative career as a professional mainstream racist.

Kurt Vonnegut is a spiritual teacher of mine, and he once said "we are what we pretend to be, so we must be careful about what we pretend to be."

Let me add a corollary: "we are what we find acceptable, so we must be careful about what we find acceptable."

Today I’ll observe that the further out you push the margin, the more of what is actually extremist hate becomes respectable and popular, rather than fringe—as, I’d argue, we can very clearly see today.

Global bullies are putting up big wins lately, it seems.

This suggests that c) what a bully always wants is to inflict more harm than whatever amount of harm that they are currently inflicting.

And that, in a system that is oriented to permit bullies to do as they please, the boundaries of permission will expand as far as the bully wants to push.

The takeaways from that essay are a) that a bully operates on a sliding scale of permission, and that b) they are always seeking to move the margins of permission out.

A bully will do what they can get away with, in other words, but they’ll also test to see if they can get away with more.

With meticulous care he sits, and the pigeons gather around once more. His sandwich, purchased from a nearby deli, is stuffed with cold cuts and coleslaw. The pigeons don’t care what it is.

He knows she won’t believe him. She won’t—how could she? Still, he hopes he can make her understand. If she will understand, then he may have a better place than his room to spend these final years. Perhaps then he’ll write. If she doesn’t understand . . . well. He hopes she will understand.

This old man—but unsure of how old, impossible to know—waits for his lost wife, and the second hand of his watch tips out the time until she arrives. He stands suddenly as if to leave, effecting a half-interested scurry of pigeons, then sways, casting about with his eyes as if unsure of a course.

He would have ridden roller coasters. He would have taken up painting. He knows so damn much about painting. He knows how roller coasters work, and why Napoleon failed in Russia. He knows how the stock market works. He knows how his circulatory system works. He has no idea how his room works.

The rest has gone; friends and foes and wife and child and children-who-may-have been. Potential lovers. Countless sunsets. The cities he would have visited—Paris, Rome, Athens, Calcutta, Seoul, Belgium, Rio. Timbuktu. He would have visited Timbuktu.

This old man has a certain place where he can go.
He has his room, and he has the sandwich. That is all he has perhaps and the sandwich is of greater value to him, now that he is old and almost wise.

He holds the sandwich, unwrapped but uneaten, and smokes, and the ash that falls from the tip of his cigarette is as gray as grey.

Pigeon eyes are as blank as greed, whether pigeons are being fed or no. Since their eyes will not change no matter what, the old man sees no point in feeding them.

The bench is painted green, and where the paint has flaked the wood beneath is gray. Gray the color of the pigeons he is not feeding. The pigeons all hope he will die soon so he will drop his sandwich. They watch him with unchanging pushpin eyes, wishing a steel-gray end to him.

This old man sits on the bench, and he is not feeding the pigeons, no.

He wears a gray wool suit, gray slacks, gray face, even the necktie. His gray hat wears a bright red feather, the only color on him.

The people who persuaded me that the dominant spirit of my country is both conservative and supremacist are conservatives.

For those who think that the most important thing in the world is persuasion, I have good news: persuasion has been happening all along. 

I didn't think used to think that Republicans were fascist. 
Now I do. 
I was persuaded. 

Who persuaded me? You'll never guess.

So I've been thinking a lot about persuasion: how it works, what it is, what it isn't, how it can be effectively.

Particularly, since our problem is a gang of bullies, I've been thinking about what persuades bullies.

By framing our current situation as a fight against fascism and supremacy, I'm told I’m passing up a real opportunity to persuade those who are engaged in these things—and persuasion is, I'm told, what’s necessary to drive real change.

It tells us where the permission levels are right now for our national gang of genocidal bullies, by which I mean the Republican Party. 

When I say things like this, I’m often admonished for being divisive or polarized.

However, I’m told the difference between burning books meant to signify certain types of people and burning cardboard meant to signify books meant to signify people is a very important distinction. 

I agree, actually.
A lot of people are alarmed by this, because they understand that burning and shooting things meant to signify certain people is always the precursor to burning and shooting the signified people.

This is nothing new these days, really. Republican office-holders and aspiring office-holders have been burning and shooting all sorts of effigies for years now, indicating the types of things and people they would like to see eliminated in one way or another.
I found this passage instructive.

I’m told it’s very important to note that the flamethrower-wielders were not burning books—again, burning books is something they are talking about doing. They were merely burning cardboard boxes, as a way of indicating other things. Read all about it.

You know what? I might have *grinned* at Jake that Monday morning in class. I really might have. 

Hey, let’s go back to Missouri, the land of congressmen wielding flamethrowers.

Another thing I’ve noticed is, though some bullies are willing to fight, and all bullies like whatever one-sided violence is permissible, bullies don’t actually like fights.

Fights, it seems, or even the promise of fights, are the opposite of permission.

Another thing that occurs to me is that since bullies operate on a sliding scale of permission, they have a pretty finely attuned radar for what is permissible, and how to skirt the margins of permissibility, and when those margins have changed.

Has any bully ever gone too far and realized it too late, after lasting damage has been done to their victim? Certainly so. Are you sorry for the bully in this scenario? Maybe. Are you *exclusively* sorry for the bully? Many are. Another thing I’ve learned from observing bullies.

If they don’t get opposed for issuing threats, then they understand that to be permission, and then they progress to actually doing it, and if that works out for them, then they progress to doing more. And sometimes much more.

I’ve noticed some other things about bullies. For example, bullies tend to operate on a sliding scale of permission. They start by pretending to do a thing to see how pretending goes for them before actually doing it. If they catch any heat, they were just joking.

So what happened? Did he get bored? Had he been bluffing? I’ll never know. Bullies don’t tend to tell you what their motivations are, and they tend to lie about their intentions even to themselves. 

This is a thing I have noticed about bullies. Maybe if you’ve had a bully you’ve noticed this too.

It’s possible that there was something anticipatory in my face that Jake didn’t like, something that said "if you want to do this, you’re going to have to fight." 

What I know for sure is that Jake wasn’t at the gap in the fence that day, or any other day.

Monday at school I saw Jake, and maybe I smiled at him in class or maybe I didn’t. I don’t remember. 1986 was a while ago. I do remember feeling a sense of anticipation different from the growing dread I’d experienced the week before.

I could tell he wasn’t kidding. 

And I slept pretty well that weekend.

This confused me, because again, I had been taught pretty clearly that one should never retaliate. 

But I said, yeah, I think so, and I did think so, too, I really did, because I was bigger than him. 

And my dad said 

well maybe you ought to clean his clock one good time, then

The next day Jake told me that on Monday after school he’d be waiting and he was going to beat the shit out me. And I told my dad this, and my dad sort of looked at me and asked me, 

well? do you think you could take him?

And again this was back in 1986, which is a time I have noticed bullies today consider to be a wonderful permissive time when everyone was much more relaxed about jokes, so I could tell that my parents were both deeply concerned and uncertain what to do about this.

Next day Jake added *actually* shoving me into his repertoire. There was a stone retaining wall in one spot, and he really biffed me into that. My parents called the school, and the school wondered if this was happening on school property, and it wasn’t.

Jake’s parents were of the opinion that boys would be boys, which led my parents to believe that Jake’s parents were assholes, but clearly it wasn’t certain what else could be done in that direction, and I added sleeping badly to my overall response.

Jake spent next day on more of the same; also by trying to trip me by kicking my feet into one another. And I responded with more of the same nothing, and by raging in impotent fury at home, which my parents noticed, which led to them calling Jake’s parents.

Jake made pointed threats about what he thought should happen to me for being a slur redacted, and he also pretended he was going to hit me and shove me, laughing when I flinched. I responded by walking as quickly as I could, so it would end more quickly, which I suppose it did.

Next day he was waiting at the gap and he used my responses the previous day to ask even meaner and more targeted personalized questions like how long I had been a slur redacted, and how much did I like being a fucking slur redacted.

Jake met me at the gap and followed me home, and asked me mean vaguely threatening questions. I had been taught in no uncertain terms that it was very important to never retaliate, so I retaliated mostly by mumbling answers and hoping he would leave me alone, which he did not.

Let’s change names to protect the innocent and call my bully Jake (even though it was Jeremy). My take on it these days is that Jake wanted to impress the older guys by being a tough guy himself and I looked like an easy mark, which I sure was.

My bully was a kid my age who ran with a tougher group of guys in my neighborhood, and by “tougher” I mean they smoked and cussed and wore jean jackets, and moreover they stood in a gap in the chain link fence, a shortcut that shaved a half mile or more off my walk.

This morning I’m sitting in appreciation for our teachers, especially early ones, and offering a farewell to a great one, who deserved more than she got, and got much that she never deserved.

She did well for as long as she could, and now she is gone. 

She will be remembered. She will be missed.

No, it is anger about the damage abuse does to other impossibly gorgeous humans, and the demand that it be stopped—*that* is the inappropriate thing. 

And Sinead O'Connor was an inappropriate woman.
In this world, abuse is not inappropriate, and anger is not inappropriate; as long as they are in service to abuse; rather, they are how the world works, and the world will reward them for it.

Exposed to the natural light of truth, burned by the moral imperative to do something about it, and scorched by our shirked responsibility to shoulder our own part of the burden—and we found that inappropriate, and many of us hated her for that. *That* was the offense.

Even if we were only exposed to the truth long enough to furnish ourselves with a reason to not care and then furnish ourselves another reason to not care that we had decided not to care, nevertheless we had been briefly exposed.

It strikes me that this was her true offense, the reason she was seen as inappropriate: her anger exposed the reality of institutional abuse, made it so immediate and present that the rest of us would have to stop and think about it.

And again came that voice rising, and my skin went gooseflesh and my hair stood on end, because she was still out there, still fierce, still angry, still confident that standing with those who are harmed is preferable to standing with those who do the harming, despite the cost.

And a few years ago, a random playlist delivered her to me again, this time singing “Queen of Denmark,” another cover, this time by John Grant, but once again so perfectly brought to life by her extraordinary gift that it seemed to have been waiting for her to come along to realize its fullness.

Another lesson: a demonstration that there’s a monetary and physical and psychological price for entering into awareness about the ways the world’s institutions accommodate corruption and abuse, a price to caring enough to have appropriate reactions.

And it seems to me that O’Connor was rather open about her own messiness, her own pain, the harm that had been done. She exposed her wounds and her raw nerves, allowing us to see the ravages of living opposed to abuses in a world arranged to accommodate abusers above any others.

No, what our society found inappropriate about O’Connor was not *that* she was angry, but what she was angry about—that is, corruption and abuse that our society felt was better ignored, the ways the most powerful human institutions protected not the vulnerable, but the abusers.

It’s fairly easy to see that our society didn’t feel she was inappropriate only because she was angry. In fact, our society believes that anger is a very appropriate response, and will often celebrate anger. Most people were angry at her, after all—they were *furious.*

But simple anger wasn't her lesson. 

Her lesson wasn’t just to *be* angry, but *why* to be angry. 

Most anger that's deemed appropriate in our society is cheap and easy. 

Appropriate anger is harder. You'll have to pay for it.

In my life I’ve sought out teachers who help me understand how to live in this truth. 

But it strikes me now that without realizing it, the first person who taught me that might have been Sinead O’Connor, who responded to abuse with anger, and was deemed inappropriate for it.

This appropriate anger is a creative and artistic thing that is not antithetical to love, but inextricably rooted in love for humanity’s impossible beauty, and scorn for those who would mar it with abuse for their own corrupt gain. 

That’s what I believe, anyway.

... that we humans have bent our societies in inappropriate reaction to this truth, have structured our institutions to press the human spirit into defaults that accommodate greed, cruelty, and abuse, and that the appropriate reaction to such corruption is anger.

I think the thing that Sinead O’Connor was teaching were lessons about appropriate reactions: that the world is a beautiful and wonderful place, full of beautiful and wonderful people, and that the appropriate response to that fact is joy and creativity and love. But also ...

It occurs to me now that perhaps I experienced her as a sort of impossibly cool older sister, the one who takes you under her wing and teaches you things about the world you haven’t known yet. 

I've been thinking about that this last week I guess. The lessons taught, and learned.

It climbed up to the sky and right down my spine; she sang about her own lost love, her own regret and memories sweet and bitter, yet somehow she was delivering to me—and, I imagine, all of us—our own experiences of something good come to a close, our own regrets, our own pain.

I only saw her perform once, in the late 90s, when she swung by on a leg of the Lilith Fair. Her set was the one I was anticipating most, and she delivered. If memory serves she closed w/one of my favorite songs, “The Last Day Of Our Acquaintance,” and her voice did that thing.

The way her voice would rise and rise, holding all the rawness and immediacy of whatever emotions she had brought to the moment, the sadness and pain and anger and defiance and joy and celebration, too, until your skin would go gooseflesh and your hair would stand on end.
And if you’re reading this far I think its safe to say you’re familiar with her music, so I don’t have to tell you her way of going from haunted and ethereal to fierce and hungry in a heartbeat.

Pesci then suggested that he’d have physically assaulted her for her effrontery if she’d been there and tried such shenanigans on his watch, and the crowd clapped and cheered to that, too, which meant that (unlike Sinead O’Connor) they were all appropriate, and so was the Church.

After she tore up the pope's photo on SNL to protest the church’s institutionalized practice of protecting their child abusers, the next week’s host, Joe Pesci, taped the photo back together to fix the rip in the collective complacency and the crowd clapped approvingly at that.

Sinead O’Connor was often inappropriate; anyway that seemed to be what a lot of people thought of her: an inappropriate woman. 

An appropriate woman sings multiplatinum hits written by Prince and then does what her handlers say and makes more hits, she doesn’t call the Catholic Church an enemy.

I just mean that my brain keeps telling me that this event—the death of a beloved musician—is something relational that it wasn’t. I guess I could say “inaccurate” but it doesn’t feel inaccurate, so I’m going with “inappropriate.” 

But maybe it’s appropriate to be inappropriate.

And it might seem odd that I say "inappropriate;" you might be thinking "dude it’s fine, you’re sad a singer you liked died, that is normal, just own your emotions" but I don’t really mean it like that; I’m not embarrassed about the inappropriateness, I’m just recognizing it.

She didn’t know me, but I guess somewhere in the reaches of my brain I decided I knew her, and then I didn’t bother to tell myself that’s what I had decided, until I heard that she was no longer with us, and now I’m telling myself a lot, and that’s not really appropriate.

This feels like losing someone who was closer than you realized—which again, she wasn’t, so I’m having an inappropriate response, it seems. 

I keep remembering and then getting a bit emotional about it—nothing histrionic or even outwardly visible but definitely emotional.

I never know how the death of a famous person is going to affect me until it happens, but usually the reaction is muted by a predictable remove. 

This hasn’t been my reaction to hearing that Sinead O’Connor is gone. (thread)
